As the present Congress is drawing towards its

ac frequent Calls for Disclosure of our sentiments with

at the ballot box. As the conductor Of DemuctAtlc
journal, have other ambition than TO be the organ

NATIONAL POLITICS.
full articles.article:
As the present Congress is drawing towards its
close, it appears be fitting opportunity 20 state the
most accurate views which can ae collected the subject
Of the Presidency aud Vice Presidency We have
ac frequent Calls for Disclosure of our sentiments with
regard 10 tcuar inds ,als for these high oces, but
the rules which regulate political course are derived
from the concentrated sentiments of the Republican parry
of the State and country, do not choose tvbeecme the
personal supporters Of any class of men Our per-
sonai preferences simply express in tangible manner
at the ballot box. As the conductor Of DemuctAtlc
journal, have other ambition than TO be the organ
Of correct rril ciples and accurate views.


During the present session Of Congress the esdug
Of the nation, acting With that wisdom and moderation
which ought 70 charscterisr the representatives OF
free People. have freely exchanged opinions the sub
]ec Of the next Presidency and VICE Presidency Coming
from various portions Of the country aud acquainted aih

toH af opinion has been formed At Washington, which viii

The General Government must forever le kept distinct and

entire, Republican principles and usages.


During the last two years. the Republican party have

in State have passed through their preliminary

high feelings OF honor will hereafter unite heart aud hand
with the democratic family Of the nation. Having passed

present state OF things favorable for the
OF Republican Republican principles perhsps
could have heen expected. From ent,led 10 The
deepest consideration, learn that the Rsb5ican tary
By J their able and talented eadvs, infrndfo make

The Prtsdency ond pce PRESIDENCY Of gveat nation


probable HOY ever that sep OF this important M.

new members will have reached Washington, fresh from
their constituents, and acquainted with their wishes and
feelings, Throughout tho next Summer much NAV be

aspettes, and to unite every member OF the democratic
any in one great effort for the honor and reputation

With regard TO The mode Of making the nomination. there
may exist some differences Of opinion among Repub.
The principle strictly the same in both caucus or
conventions; only happens TO differ little ia the mode
OF exercise. The ground work is the concentration Of

mon country


his account may be relied upon with some degree Of
confidence as being the present state of national politics

anoer time We may enlarge the subject more fully,
/ but this viii be sufficient now


Having stated therefore the views of the panuhcau

party rc!alve . the next Presidency, may be inquired
what great and prominent hive been placed by fortune

Jackson. Without descending 10 ice the imprudent
mannerin which all these distinguished men are some
feaed ny Their respective parzans opponents we have
no hesaon IN saying, that perhaps nation could array

hese therefore, arc the distinguished names before

AS we SAID before. the powerful Republican party, as
sembled by their representatives delegates in caucus

some devoted friend of his, having sources OF M.


formation in Washington, if not here present, and
was intended to give direction to the public sent'-
ment in New York, where the people are to be
disciplined under the new system OF tactics COM
piled here, we have no more doubt than we have


OF the truth of any thing Of which have not personal


knowledge OF things unseen, we only Judge from

OF this article, so very remarkable from the coin
cilence of tlme and circumstances occurring here,
the intelligent reader will need no analysis. There


are one or two prominent points in it, however, to


which it may savc him some trouble to direct his
/ attention.


What we shall first remark is that the editor Of


the Advocate, in that article, is evidently not ex-


pressing his own views, but obeying the lnstruc
| tons of Others He admits that he IS one OF the
organized' lie has g mo other ambition as an

Of sentiment is between that print, in New York,


and the Telegraph. published in the City OF Wash

1aE ry1roRArn Tns NATIONAL ADvocArS.

of its rc.vs, and the means organ ofcorcc principles and
Of lis defence. accurate y,ews


Verify, here arc pair Of !" uigans."


Not only has the Editor of the Advocate no am
biton, but he has no opinion, OF his own for he
is ready to give "a cordial warn,, and honest
support'-.o what, Or to whoms To any thing that
he knows or approves Not at all-but to some.
thing that he cannot know, and, therefore, cannot
tell whether he approves or not. This is the very
climax and perfection Of " Improvement Of condi-


tom that suits the party organization, which a
bold attempt is now making to extend, from the


sphere Of tie State Of New York, to the sphere of
this Union. The chess-board of State is not
large enough ior game. wot thy TO employ skill
full tactican-- nor, Me may add, is the stake large
enough.


The next thing VIC shall advert 70 is the News
from Washington which this article communicates.
We had supposed, simply enough it seems, that
both Houses Of Congress had been deeply engaged


the business Of legislation, for which the People
sent them here. We believe still OF the large
majority Of Congress. Put others, it now appears.
have been very differently employed and a con-


4cutraiion Of opinion has been formed at Washing
ton" during the late Stssion. With what secrecy


nnst not these operations have been carried on,
when the first suspicion Of combination OF organ
izaton is produced BY vote in the Senate which
plectrtes every body! With what confidence in
The ot their plans do they not tell Us, that
This concentratonn will, beyond doubt, be en-
tered iato bN the new Members Of both Houses
How is this ascertained Rut, suppose il lie true,
what then Are they 70 make President and Vice
President We had thought that 1HE PEopIl had
a VOICE IN this matter. We had thought, moreo-
YER, that the very ground of opposition 10 this Ad


ninlstation, n, ht or wrong was. that the Presi-


dent was not elected primarily by the People, but,
in the last resor by the House OF Representatives.


That election, however, was made in the mode
prescribed by the Constitution and this 6 concen-
tration' Id, aots.!ng 70 do with that musty old
parchment, being only designed 70 save the Peo-
pie from telr own worst enemies, themselves, BY
saving them from he trouble Of thinking Of public
aiialrs-.tur which purpose, il the plan succeed,
tyranny Is to be established here, which ha. com
menced with the prescription ot this press, and


viii level Unfortunately whatever stands in the


way of its usurpations. We have no doubt, now


that consultations hare been held here DUNG the
late session, and that, in TRUTH the . leaders'--


yes, the 8, able and talented leaders, really in
tend to make a nomination of their own at the


next ses>ion---f they can FIRST organize the Press
and by its aid STIR up the People to great ia
natcism, az 10 allow themselves to he trnd down
ly the Juggernaut OF new p4 ty--ot a party as
i4lch more 70 be dreaded OF deprecated than any
resent party, as secrecy, combination, and pros
cription, IN affairs Of Government, arc more con.
demnabe than upfnness. independence Of thought


ami action, aat federation cardinal! principles in


the creed which W we're taught III inancy--which


@ehase praetleed upon III lnaturer years, and which


We shall ncvtt abandon, until we become as due


tile and obsequous ''the leaders" would have us
Ihs holdest part of this Article, however, is that


which undertakes TO name +" the great and promi.


ncnt men, VINO nave been placed by fortune.
accident, talent. or public ser,ice,,'' (fortune and


stcident bath taking precedent Of talent and ser


vices before the country, in the position Of can


ddates for the high Offices Of President and


Vice President. and the order IN which they are
placed i tnore remarkable, than the selection Of


names. Clay, Clinton, and Calhoun--and Adams

to this Editor, Offers two candidates for the two


stations. 10 Of these two, il is obviously the
